questions.text: Liver synthesizes all of the following except:(NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Immunoglobulins

 

Explanation

 

Immunoglobulins are produced by plasma cells.

 

Essentially all the albumin and fibrinogen of the plasma proteins, as well as 50 to 80 per cent of the globulins, are formed in the liver. The remainder of the globulins are formed almost entirely in the lymphoid tissues. They are mainly the gamma globulins that constitute the antibodies used in the immune system.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Albumin: Exclusion, as albumin is a major protein synthesized by the liver, which is the most abundant protein in plasma, playing crucial roles in maintaining osmotic pressure and transporting substances such as drugs and hormones.

 

Option B. Coagulation factors: Exclusion, as these are primarily produced by the liver, including factors such as prothrombin and fibrinogen.

 

Option C. Acute phase proteins: Exclusion, as the liver significantly ramps up production of these proteins in response to inflammation or infection (like C-reactive protein (CRP) and serum amyloid A (SAA), which play roles in modulating the immune response and inflammation).

 

Educational Objective:

 

Common plasma proteins synthesized by the liver are:

 

  • Albumin
  • Coagulation/clotting factors
  • Acute-phase proteins
  • Steroid binding and other hormone-binding proteins

questions.text: Which of the following incisions is used for Appendicectomy? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Grid iron incision

 

The grid iron incision, also known as the McArthur incision, is the preferred surgical approach for an appendectomy. This incision is made at the McBurney point, which is located one-third of the distance from the anterior superior iliac spine to the umbilicus. The incision is muscle-splitting rather than cutting, which helps in minimizing muscle damage and promotes quicker recovery.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Kocher's incision: This is used for open cholecystectomy. It is a right subcostal incision, typically employed for gallbladder surgeries.

 

Option B. Morris incision: This is a flank incision used for accessing the retroperitoneal space, typically for renal surgeries.

 

Option D. Pfannensteil incision: This is a lower abdominal, transverse suprapubic incision often used for gynecological surgeries, such as cesarean sections.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The grid iron (McArthur) incision is the standard incision used for appendectomy, made at the McBurney point and characterized by a muscle-splitting approach.

questions.text: Modified shock index is calculated using? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. HR/MAP

 

Modified shock index = HR/MAP

 

A shock index >0.9 is indicative of higher mortality.

 

HR: Heart rate

 

MAP: Mean arterial pressure

 

SBP: Systolic blood pressure

 

DBP: Diastolic blood pressure

 

# Commonly confused:

 

Formula for shock index= Heart rate/ systolic blood pressure

 

Educational Objective :

 

Modified shock index = HR/MAP

questions.text: Identify the liver segment star marked in the image below:  (INICET May 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. V

 

Segment V of the liver is highlighted in green in this CT scan. The CT section shown is taken below the portal vein, allowing a cross-section of the portal vein before its bifurcation to be seen.

 

A horizontal plane known as the portal plane divides the liver where the portal vein bifurcates and becomes horizontal. This divides each section of the liver into superior and inferior segments:

 

  • Left lateral section: segment II above and segment III below the portal plane
  • Left medial section: segment IVa above and segment Ib below the portal plane
  • Right anterior (or medial) section: segment VIll above and segment V below the portal plane
  • Right posterior (or lateral section): segment VIl above and segment VI below the portal plane

 

Other Options:

 

Option B (IVa): Incorrect because Segment IVa is located in the left medial section of the liver and is positioned above the portal plane. This segment does not correlate with the green highlighted area in the provided image.

 

Option C (VII): Incorrect as Segment VII is part of the right posterior (or lateral) section of the liver and is located above the portal plane, unlike the depicted segment.

 

Option D (I): Incorrect because Segment I, also known as the caudate lobe, is uniquely positioned and does not conform to the typical left-right segmentation. It is not visible in the typical transverse sections used for identifying other segments like V.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: Match the following E. coli with their respective pathogenesis? (INICET NOV 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) A-1, B-2, C-3, D-4

 

The correctly matched pairs are as follows:

 

1. ETEC (Enterotoxigenic E. coli)

 

  • Mechanism: Produces a heat-stable toxin and causes activation of guanylyl cyclase.
  • Match: A. Produces a heat-stable toxin and causes activation of guanylyl cyclase.

 

2. EIEC (Enteroinvasive E. coli)

 

  • Mechanism: Invades intestinal mucosal cells.
  • Match: B. Invades intestinal mucosal cells.

 

3. EHEC (Enterohemorrhagic E. coli)

 

  • Mechanism: Produces a toxin against endothelial cells.
  • Match: C. Produces a toxin against endothelial cells.

 

4. EPEC (Enteropathogenic E. coli)

 

  • Mechanism: Adheres to the mucosal surface and causes effacement of microvilli.
  • Match: D. Adheres to the mucosal surface and causes effacement of microvilli.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: Which of the following hormones use receptor tyrosine kinase signaling? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Insulin

 

Insulin uses the receptor tyrosine kinase signaling to exert its functions.

 

Insulin receptor is a tetramer, formed by four glycoprotein subunits (two α-subunits and two β-subunits). The α-subunits protrude out of the cell and the β-subunits protrude inside the cell. The α and β subunits are linked to each other by disulfide bonds. Intracellular surfaces of α-subunits have the enzyme activity – protein kinase (tyrosine kinase) activity.

 

When insulin binds with α-subunits of the receptor protein, the tyrosine kinase at the β-subunit (that protrudes into the cell) is activated by means of autophosphorylation.

 

Activated tyrosine kinase acts on many intracellular enzymes by phosphorylating or dephosphorylating them so that some of the enzymes are activated while others are inactivated

 

Other hormones acting in a similar fashion includes

 

  • Growth factors like VEGF, PDGF, FGF, NGF
  • hormones acting via cytokine receptor - Prolactin, Growth hormone

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. TSH (Thyroid Stimulating Hormone): Incorrect. TSH acts through a G protein-coupled receptor (GPCR), not a receptor tyrosine kinase. It stimulates the thyroid gland to produce thyroid hormones by activating the adenylyl cyclase signaling pathway.

 

Option C. TRH (Thyrotropin-Releasing Hormone): Incorrect. TRH also utilizes G protein-coupled receptors and primarily influences the pituitary gland to release TSH, using intracellular signaling mechanisms involving phospholipase C.

 

Option D. MSH (Melanocyte-Stimulating Hormone): Incorrect. MSH binds to melanocortin receptors, which are GPCRs, and is involved in a variety of functions including skin pigmentation and appetite regulation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Insulin uniquely uses receptor tyrosine kinase signaling among the options listed, activating complex pathways that are essential for regulating glucose metabolism and other metabolic processes in the body.

questions.text: Identify the finding marked by the arrow in the below image: (INICET Nov 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Vossius ring

 

  • The image shows a Vossius ring, which is a circular ring of faint or stippled opacity seen on the anterior surface of the lens.
  • It is caused by brown amorphous granules of pigment lying on the capsule of the lens and is usually seen after blunt trauma to the eye and orbit.
  • The force of the blow drives the cornea and iris backward, producing an impression of the iris on the lens.
  • The ring usually has about the same diameter as the contracted pupil.
  • The resorption of the pigment results in discrete subcapsular opacities.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Weiss ring: Is a floater which may be seen by the patient as a circle or other large solitary lesion. It is the detached former attachment to the margin of the optic disc. It is seen in posterior vitreous detachment and is not confirmatory. It is seen in the image below.

 

 

Option C. A Fleischer's ring: Is usually observed in keratoconus, representing epithelial iron deposits. It is seen best with a cobalt blue filter.

 

 

Option D. Kayser-Fleischer ring: Is observed in Wilson's disease, due to intraocular deposition of copper. A brownish-yellow zone is seen in the peripheral Descemet membrane of the cornea. Anterior capsular cataract, also knowns as a sunflower cataract may be seen in some patients.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Vossius ring is an important clinical marker of previous blunt trauma to the eye, characterized by pigment imprint from the iris on the lens surface, mirroring the size of the contracted pupil at the time of impact.

questions.text: You discover that there is evidence of cardiac malformation in a fetus during a routine US scan at 16 weeks. What is the minimum level of fasting blood sugar at which you can suspect overt diabetes? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 126 mg/dL

 

Overt diabetes in a patient is diagnosed based on specific blood glucose levels. The criteria for diagnosing overt diabetes are:

 

  • Fasting blood sugar: ≥ 126 mg/dL
  • Random blood sugar: ≥ 200 mg/dL
  • HbA1c: ≥ 6.5%

 

During pregnancy, maternal hyperglycemia, especially during the first trimester when organogenesis occurs, increases the risk of fetal congenital malformations, including cardiac malformations. This is particularly true for women with pre-gestational diabetes, not gestational diabetes.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. 106 mg/dL: This is incorrect. A fasting blood sugar level of 106 mg/dL does not meet the threshold for diagnosing overt diabetes.

 

Option C. 116 mg/dL: This is incorrect. A fasting blood sugar level of 116 mg/dL is higher than normal but still below the threshold for diagnosing overt diabetes.

 

Option D. 130 mg/dL: This is incorrect. Although higher than the threshold, the minimum level to suspect overt diabetes is 126 mg/dL, not 130 mg/dL.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Overt diabetes in pregnancy is diagnosed with a fasting blood sugar level of ≥ 126 mg/dL, and maternal hyperglycemia.

questions.text: A pregnant woman presents with obstructed labor and is grossly dehydrated. Investigations reveal fetal demise. What will be the management? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Cesarean section

 

Explanation:

 

  • Obstructed labor is a direct indication for an emergency cesarean section
  • Obstructed labor happens when despite good uterine contractions, labor does not progress due to problems in the maternal pelvis/ fetus or a mechanical obstruction
  • Features of Obstructed Labor:
  • Maternal exhaustion and dehydration
  • Abdominal examination
    • Upper segment is tonically contracted with no relaxation The wall becomes thicker
    • Lower segment becomes distended and thinned out
    • Fetal parts not easily felt
    • Round ligaments taut and tender
    • Bandl’s ring is felt (Retraction ring)
    • Fetal heart rate absent
  • Vaginal exam
    • Vagina feels hot and dry
    • Cervix hangs loosely like a curtain
    • Caput +++
    • Moulding +++
    • Head feels jammed in the pelvis
  • The mainstay of management will be to start IV fluids and broad-spectrum antibiotics.
  • Emergency LSCS is the rule in Obstructed labor even in a dead fetus

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Craniotomy: This is a destructive fetal operation which is not preferred anymore even in a non-viable fetus/ dead fetus. It can be done if ffacilities for immediate cesarean are not available.  The main indications for fetal craniotomy are:

 

  • Cephalic presentation with obstructed labour
  • Hydrocephalus in a living fetus
  • Interlocking head of twins
  • Aftercoming head of breech

 

Option B. Decapitation: It is severing of the fetal head from the trunk. It is a destructive operation and again is not preferred unless facilities for emergency LSCS are not available or in exceptional circumstances. Indications are

 

  • Neglected shoulder with a dead fetus
  • Locked twins

 

Option D. Forceps extraction: Instrumental delivery is contra-indicated in obstructed labor. CPD should be ruled out prior to applying an instrument (Forceps or vacuum)

 

Educational Objective:

 

In cases of obstructed labor, an emergency cesarean section is the recommended management, even if the fetus is deceased.

 

Ref: Page no 421, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Obstetrics 8th edition

questions.text:
A 40-year-old male presents with increased thirst and increased frequency and volume of urination. He has no other symptoms. His random blood sugar was 205 mg/dl, what appropriate investigations should be done? (INICET Nov 2023)

 

  1. HbA1c
  2. Urine ACR
  3. Echocardiography
  4. Fundoscopy
  5. ECG
  6. Serum protein electrophoresis
questions.solution:
Ans. D) i, ii, iv, v

 

The patient presents with hyperglycemia (random blood sugar of 205 mg/dl), indicating diabetes. The appropriate investigations for a newly diagnosed diabetic patient are:

 

1. HbA1c: To assess long-term glycemic control and confirm the diagnosis of diabetes.

 

2. Urine ACR (Albumin-to-Creatinine Ratio): To screen for diabetic nephropathy, as microalbuminuria is an early sign of kidney damage.

 

4. Fundoscopy: To check for diabetic retinopathy and other microvascular changes in the eyes.

 

5. ECG: To screen for any cardiovascular complications, as diabetes increases the risk of heart disease.

 

Other Options:

 

3. Echocardiography: Not a routine screening test for diabetes unless there is a specific indication, such as suspected heart failure or structural heart disease.

 

6. Serum protein electrophoresis: Not indicated in the routine evaluation of diabetes and is used to diagnose conditions like multiple myeloma.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For a newly diagnosed diabetic patient, essential investigations include HbA1c, urine ACR, fundoscopy, and ECG to assess glycemic control, kidney function, eye health, and cardiovascular risk, respectively.

questions.text: Location of Bartholin cyst at the vaginal orifice is at? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Posterior 1/3rd

 

Bartholin glands are located at the posterior part of the vaginal introitus. These glands are responsible for secreting mucus to provide lubrication for the vagina. A Bartholin cyst occurs when the duct of the Bartholin gland becomes blocked, leading to the accumulation of fluid.

 

  • Location: The Bartholin glands are situated at the lower part of the vaginal opening, specifically at the junction between the posterior one-third and the anterior two-thirds of the labia minora. Thus, when a Bartholin cyst forms, it typically presents at this posterior one-third region of the vaginal orifice.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A Bartholin cyst is located at the posterior one-third of the vaginal orifice, at the margin of the labia minora and the vaginal introitus.

questions.text: A 65-year-old male with chronic alcohol use was admitted with complaints of unsteady gait, difficulty in seeing, and appears confused. Which vitamin is he deficient in? (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Vit B1

 

The patient's symptoms of unsteady gait (ataxia), difficulty in seeing (ophthalmoplegia), and confusion (global confusion) are characteristic features of Wernicke's encephalopathy.

 

Wernicke's encephalopathy is a neurological disorder caused by a deficiency of Vitamin B1 (thiamine). The mnemonic "GOA" (Global confusion, Ophthalmoplegia, Ataxia) is often used to remember the triad of symptoms associated with this condition.

 

Chronic alcohol use is a common cause of thiamine deficiency, leading to Wernicke's encephalopathy. The treatment involves administering high doses of parenteral thiamine.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Vit B12: Deficiency of Vitamin B12 typically presents with symptoms such as anemia, glossitis, peripheral neuropathy, and in severe cases, subacute combined degeneration of the spinal cord, which does not match the clinical presentation in this scenario.

 

Option C. Vit C: Vitamin C deficiency leads to scurvy, characterized by symptoms like bleeding gums, petechiae, and poor wound healing, which are not observed in this patient.

 

Option D. Vit B3: Deficiency of Vitamin B3 (niacin) causes pellagra, which presents with the triad of diarrhea, dermatitis, and dementia. This does not align with the patient's symptoms of ataxia, ophthalmoplegia, and confusion.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Wernicke's encephalopathy, characterized by the triad of global confusion, ophthalmoplegia, and ataxia (mnemonic GOA), is caused by a deficiency of Vitamin B1 (thiamine) and commonly occurs in individuals with chronic alcohol use.

questions.text: A 30-year-old man has chosen to undergo vasectomy. What advice will you give this patient regarding the use of contraception post-vasectomy? (FMGE JANUARY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 12 – 16 weeks

 

After undergoing a vasectomy, it is important to understand that while the procedure is highly effective at preventing pregnancy, it is not immediately effective. Sperm can still be present in the reproductive system for some time following the surgery. Therefore, it is crucial to use an alternative form of contraception until a follow-up test confirms that there are no longer any viable sperm present. It is estimated that this sterilization technique is effective after about 3 months or 20 ejaculates to empty the stored semen. A semen analysis report confirming azoospermia is essential to confirm this.

 

Educational Objective:

 

After a vasectomy, alternative contraception should be used until a semen analysis confirms azoospermia, usually around 12-16 weeks post-surgery.

 

Ref: Dutta textbook of obstetrics page 32

questions.text: Which of the following disease is exclusively seen in females? (INICET May 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Rett syndrome

 

Rett syndrome is a rare genetic disorder that affects brain development and results in severe intellectual and physical disability. It is nearly always seen in females. Males with the genetic mutation for Rett syndrome usually die shortly after birth.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Asperger syndrome: It is a milder variant of autism and can occur in both males and females, although it is more commonly diagnosed in males.

 

Option C. Selective mutism: An anxiety disorder in which a person who is normally capable of speech cannot speak in specific situations or to specific people. It affects both males and females.

 

Option D. Atypical autism: Also known as Pervasive Developmental Disorder - Not Otherwise Specified (PDD-NOS), it can occur in both males and females.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Rett syndrome is a rare genetic neurodevelopmental disorder almost exclusively seen in females. It is caused by mutations in the MECP2 gene located on the X chromosome. It is characterized by normal development for the first 6-18 months of life followed by a loss of purposeful hand skills, severe language impairment, and motor abnormalities.

 

Reference: A Short Textbook of Psychiatry, 7th edition, Page No 165.

questions.text: Below is the air pollution index chart for four consecutive days at the Delhi station. What is the categorization of the air quality index for November 23rd? [NEET PG 2021]
questions.solution:
Ans. (d) Severe

 

Based on the information provided in the query, the air quality index on November 23rd is measured at 407, falling under the severe category.

 

AIR QUALITY INDEX (AQI)

 

A tool used for effective communication of air quality status on a scale that is easily comprehensible. Complex air quality data of various pollutants are compiled to give a single score (index value), nomenclature and color that determines the air pollution of that particular location.

 

Eight pollutants are taken into consideration to calculate the AQI -

 

  1. PM10 (Airborne particulate matter with a diameter of 10 microns or less)
  2. PM2.5 (Airborne particulate matter with a diameter of 2.5 microns or less)
  3. NO2 (Nitrogen dioxide)
  4. SO2 (Sulfur dioxide)
  5. CO (Carbon monoxide)
  6. 03 (Ozone/Trioxygen)
  7. NH3 (Ammonia)
  8. Pb (Lead)

 

AQl categories and the range are as follows:

 

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: Which anti-TB drug causes red colour vision defects or optic neuropathy?(FMGE Jan 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Ethambutol

 

Ethambutol is used in the treatment of tuberculosis. One of the well-known side effects of ethambutol is optic neuropathy, which can lead to color vision defects, particularly with the perception of red and green. Patients on ethambutol are usually monitored for visual acuity and color vision changes.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Rifampicin: Rifampicin is used to treat various bacterial infections, including tuberculosis (TB). While it has a range of side effects, red color vision defects or optic neuropathy are not typically associated with rifampicin. It is more commonly known to cause orange discoloration of body fluids.

 

Option C. INH (Isoniazid): INH, or isoniazid, is another first-line anti-TB medication. Its side effects can include peripheral neuropathy, which is why it is often given with pyridoxine (vitamin B6) to mitigate this risk. However, INH is not commonly associated with red color vision defects or optic neuropathy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Ethambutol, an anti-TB drug, can cause optic neuropathy and red color vision defects, necessitating regular eye exams for patients on this medication.

questions.text: All of the following are criteria for diagnosis of DKA except: (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) S. Potassium < 3.5 mEq/L

 

Diabetic ketoacidosis (DKA) is a serious complication of diabetes characterized by hyperglycemia, ketosis, and metabolic acidosis. The diagnostic criteria for DKA typically include:

 

  • Hyperglycemia: Blood glucose levels greater than 250 mg/dL.
  • Ketosis: Presence of ketones in the blood or urine.
  • Metabolic Acidosis: Indicated by an arterial pH of less than 7.3, a serum bicarbonate level of less than 15-18 mEq/L, and an anion gap greater than 12.

 

S. Potassium < 3.5 mEq/L is not a diagnostic criterion for DKA. Although potassium imbalance is common in DKA due to shifts between the intracellular and extracellular compartments, serum potassium levels are not used as a diagnostic criterion. Potassium levels can vary and might be normal, elevated, or decreased, depending on the stage of DKA and the treatment administered.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. S. glucose > 250 mg/dL: This is a diagnostic criterion for DKA as it confirms the presence of significant hyperglycemia.

 

Option B. Arterial pH < 7.3: This indicates metabolic acidosis, which is a key component of DKA.

 

Option C. Anion gap > 12: An increased anion gap signifies high anion gap metabolic acidosis (HAGMA), which is typical in DKA due to the presence of ketone bodies.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The diagnostic criteria for DKA include hyperglycemia, ketosis, and metabolic acidosis with an increased anion gap. Potassium levels, while important to monitor and manage in DKA, are not part of the diagnostic criteria.

questions.text: Out of the options given below the most common habit-forming drug is? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Heroin

 

Heroin is an opioid and is the most commonly abused opioid. Heroin has the highest dependence potential among all drugs listed. It is highly addictive, and users can develop a strong physical dependence, leading to withdrawal symptoms if the drug is not taken.

 

Most commonly abused drugs: This can vary from one country to another. Generally, alcohol, tobacco, cannabis, opioids are most commonly abused drugs:

 

  • Alcohol is the most common Used/Abused Substance in the World
  • Tobacco is the most common Used/Abused Substance in India
  • Cannabis is the most common “illegally” used drug in India as well as world, though its dependence potential is relatively lower.
  • Heroin is the most commonly abused opioid, and is the drug with highest dependence potential amongst all the drugs.

 

Other Options

 

Option A. Ketamine: Ketamine is a dissociative anesthetic with some potential for abuse, but it is not as commonly abused or as habit-forming.

 

Option C. LSD (Lysergic acid diethylamide) is a hallucinogen. It can be abused, but it does not have the same level of physical dependence potential.

 

Option D. Phencyclidine (PCP): PCP is a dissociative drug with some potential for abuse, but it is not as commonly abused or as habit-forming drug.

 

Educational Objective

 

Common habit-forming drugs:

 

  • Cannabis
  • Opioids
  • Amphetamine and prescription stimulants
  • Ecstasy
  • Cocaine

 

Heroin is the most common drug which is habit forming or in other words can cause physical dependence in which a patient gets withdrawal if he does not take the drug.

questions.text: A 48-year-old smoker presents with yellow, copious, foul-smelling sputum that increases significantly in the morning after getting up and on changing posture. He has had this problem for a few years. What will be the first differential diagnosis? (FMGE Jan 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Bronchiectasis

 

Explanation

 

The correct answer is bronchiectasis. The key features in this case include the presence of copious, foul-smelling sputum that increases significantly in the morning and with postural changes. These features are highly suggestive of bronchiectasis, a condition characterized by chronic dilation and infection of the bronchi. This leads to the production of large amounts of sputum, particularly after changes in posture due to the drainage of secretions from the dilated airways.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Asthma: Typically presents with wheezing, shortness of breath, and a dry or mildly productive cough. Asthma is diagnosed with spirometry, showing reversible airway obstruction.

 

Option B. Pneumonia: Usually presents acutely with fever, cough, and purulent sputum. It is less likely to cause symptoms that have persisted for years.

 

Option D. Lung cancer: May present with chronic cough and hemoptysis but is less likely to produce copious, foul-smelling sputum that increases with postural changes over several years.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Bronchiectasis should be considered in patients with chronic, copious, foul-smelling sputum that varies with posture, especially in the context of a history of smoking or recurrent respiratory infections. Recognizing these features can prompt appropriate diagnostic imaging, such as a CT scan showing characteristic tram-track or signet ring appearances.

questions.text: Identify the type of drain: (INICET NOV 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Closed

 

The image displays a Romovac drain placed after mastectomy, which is a closed-type drain. Drains are utilized at surgical sites to collect air or fluid buildup, promoting wound healing by preventing cavity formation. Drains can be prophylactic in elective surgeries and therapeutic in emergency surgeries, with open, semi-open, and closed types.

 

They carry out their actions through suction

 

  • Eg. Romovac drain, Jackson Pratt drain.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Open: They are based on the principle of gravity or capillary effect

 

  • Eg. Corrugated drain, Foley’s catheter etc.\

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Romovac drain is a closed negative suction drain placed in subcutaneous tissue and indicated in modified radical mastectomy, subcutaneous swelling excision, and amputations. Other specialized drains include chest drains for air removal from the pleural cavity and T-tubes for bile drainage after surgical exploration of the bile duct.

questions.text: A baby assessed 5 minutes after birth is found to be pink, with blue extremities, and irregular respiration. Heart rate is 80 beats per minute. There is grimace and some flexion. What is the Apgar score for this baby? (INICET NOV 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 5

 

The Apgar score for this baby will be 5.

 

 

  • Color: body pink, extremities blue: score-1
  • Heart rate: 80 beats per minute: score 1
  • Grimace: Score-1
  • Some flexion: Score-1
  • Irregular respiration: Score-1

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Apgar score is used to quickly assess the overall health of a newborn, with a score of 5 indicating the need for some medical intervention but not immediate resuscitation.

questions.text: Bilirubin is measured as mg/dl in which scale? (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Continuous

 

Explanation:

 

Bilirubin is measured in milligrams per decilitre (mg/dl), which is a continuous scale. Continuous quantitative data, where multiple values can exist between any two given values, is measured on a continuous or metric scale.

 

Such as bilirubin levels of 4 mg/dl, 4.1 mg/dl, 4.25 mg/dl, 6 mg/dl, 7 mg/dl, 10 mg/dl, and 11.4 mg/dl, illustrate the continuous nature of the measurement, with numerous possible values between any two points.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Ordinal: This option is incorrect because ordinal scales represent ordered categories or ranks. This is discrete data

 

Option B. Nominal: This option is incorrect because nominal scales represent categories or names without any inherent order or quantitative value. This is discrete data

 

Option C. Discrete: This option is incorrect because discrete scales involve counting or whole numbers, whereas bilirubin measurements can have fractional or decimal values.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Bilirubin is measured in milligrams per decilitre (mg/dl), which falls under the continuous scale, as it allows for numerous possible values between any two given points, reflecting the precise quantitative nature of the measurement.

questions.text: A middle aged female presents with headache. Radiological examination reveals a 2 cm mass attached to the dura. Which of the following will most likely be observed on histopathology? (FMGE JAN 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Psammoma Bodies with Whirling

 

  • Psammoma bodies with whirling are particularly associated with certain tumors, such as papillary thyroid carcinoma, meningioma (a type of brain tumor that often arises from the dura), and serous ovarian tumors.
  • The presence of psammoma bodies with a characteristic whirling appearance in the histopathological examination of the mass attached to the dura would strongly suggest a meningioma as the likely diagnosis.
  • It is benign tumor, arise from the meningothelial cells of the arachnoid.
  • The most common cytogenetic abnormality is the loss of chromosome 22q

 

 

  • Psammoma bodies are concentric calcific structures.
  • They appear as round, laminated calcifications under the microscope. The presence of psammoma bodies in a tumor can provide important diagnostic clues.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Fried Egg Appearance: This appearance is typically associated with oligodendrogliomas, not meningiomas.

 

Option B. Antony A and B Areas: These areas are characteristic of schwannomas.

 

Option C. Verrucae Bodies: These bodies are not related to meningiomas or the described clinical scenario.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Psammoma bodies with a whirling appearance are characteristic of meningiomas, a type of brain tumor that often arises from the dura.

questions.text: Best test for the diagnosis of disease malaria species is: [INICET MAY 2024]
questions.solution:
Ans. (a) Thin smear with Giemsa

 

Thin smear with Giemsa stain is the best method for identifying malaria species. This is because thin smears allow for detailed observation of the morphological characteristics of the malaria parasites within red blood cells. The Giemsa stain helps to highlight these features clearly, enabling the identification of the different Plasmodium species based on their unique structures.

 

Thin Smear Usage: Thin smears are used for speciation as they provide a detailed view of the parasites' morphology. This allows for differentiation among the four Plasmodium species (P. vivax, P. falciparum, P. malariae, and P. ovale) by examining the shapes and forms of the parasites within the red blood cells. Thin smears enable the visualization of specific features such as the ring form, amoeboid form, and schizonts in P. vivax, as well as multiple rings and banana-shaped gametocytes in P. falciparum.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Thick smear with Giemsa: Thick smears are primarily used for quantification of parasites and for genus identification but are not ideal for speciation because the density of the sample can obscure detailed morphological features.

 

Option C. Thin smear with acridine orange: Acridine orange is a fluorescent stain used for rapid screening but is less effective than Giemsa for detailed species identification. It is better suited for initial diagnosis rather than detailed speciation.

 

Option D. QBC (Quantitative Buffy Coat): QBC is a method used for detecting malaria parasites based on fluorescence microscopy. While it is rapid and sensitive, it does not provide detailed morphological information necessary for accurate species identification.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Thin smear with Giemsa stain is the best method for detailed malaria species identification due to its ability to highlight specific morphological features of the Plasmodium parasites.

questions.text: DNA repair gene defect with increased risk of skin cancer is a feature of: (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Xeroderma pigmentosum

 

Xeroderma pigmentosum (XP) is a rare autosomal recessive disorder characterized by a defect in the nucleotide excision repair (NER) gene. This defect impairs the body's ability to repair DNA damage caused by ultraviolet (UV) light, leading to a significantly increased risk of developing skin cancers, including basal cell carcinoma, squamous cell carcinoma, and melanoma, even at a young age.

 

Patients with xeroderma pigmentosum often exhibit extreme sensitivity to sunlight, with symptoms such as severe sunburn, freckling, and pigmentation changes. Over time, the accumulation of unrepaired DNA damage increases the likelihood of malignant transformations in skin cells.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Bloom syndrome: Bloom syndrome is also associated with increased cancer risk, but it does not specifically present with a high risk of skin cancers due to UV sensitivity. It involves a different DNA repair pathway (homologous recombination repair) and is characterized by short stature, sun-sensitive skin changes, and a predisposition to various cancers.

 

Option C. Ataxia telangiectasia: Ataxia telangiectasia is a condition caused by mutations in the ATM gene, affecting the repair of DNA double-strand breaks. While it increases the risk of leukemia and lymphoma, it is not primarily associated with an increased risk of skin cancers due to UV sensitivity.

 

Option D. Lynch syndrome: Lynch syndrome (hereditary nonpolyposis colorectal cancer) involves mutations in mismatch repair (MMR) genes and is associated with an increased risk of colorectal, endometrial, and other cancers, but not specifically skin cancers or UV-related cancers.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Xeroderma pigmentosum is characterized by a defect in the Nucleotide Excision Repair (NER) gene, leading to increased sensitivity to UV light and a significantly elevated risk of developing skin cancers.

choices.text: 4 contractions in 20 min and 8 contractions in 60 min with changes in cervix

questions.text: All of the following are the diagnostic criteria for preterm labor except?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Cervix posterior in position

 

Explanation:

 

Preterm labor (PTL) is labor that occurs before the 37th week of gestation. Accurate diagnosis involves evaluating several key criteria:

 

  • Contractions: At least one regular contraction every 10 minutes, or 4 contractions in 20 minutes, or 8 contractions in 60 minutes, with or without pain.
  • Cervical Changes: Cervical dilation greater than 2 cm and more than 80% effacement are significant indicators of preterm labor.

 

The incorrect statement is Option D. A cervix that is posterior in position is not a diagnostic criterion for preterm labor. Instead, the cervix's position may be less relevant than its dilation and effacement in the diagnosis of preterm labor.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. 4 contractions in 20 min and 8 contractions in 60 min with changes in cervix: Correct. Regular contractions that meet the criteria of 4 in 20 minutes or 8 in 60 minutes, along with changes in the cervix, are used to diagnose preterm labor.

 

Option B. Cervical dilatation > 2 cm: Correct. Cervical dilation greater than 2 cm is a diagnostic criterion for preterm labor.

 

Option C. More than 80 percent effaced cervix: Correct. Cervical effacement greater than 80% is another diagnostic criterion for preterm labor.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The cervix being in a posterior position is not a diagnostic criterion for preterm labor. The diagnosis involves assessing contraction patterns and cervical changes such as dilation and effacement.

 

Ref: Page no 366, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Obstetrics, 8th edition

questions.text: A South Asian fruit farmer presented with fever, breathlessness, and encephalitis. What can be the most likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Nipah virus

 

The Nipah virus is known to be transmitted by fruit bats, specifically the Pteropus species, which are commonly found in South Asia. The virus can cause severe respiratory illness and encephalitis in humans, symptoms that match the presentation in this case (fever, breathlessness, and encephalitis). The close association between fruit farming and fruit bats increases the risk of transmission, especially in South Asia where the Nipah virus is more prevalent.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Zika virus: Zika virus is primarily transmitted by Aedes mosquitoes and is known for causing fever, rash, joint pain, and conjunctivitis. It does not cause severe respiratory symptoms or encephalitis as described in this case.

 

Option C. Malaria: Malaria is caused by Plasmodium species and transmitted by Anopheles mosquitoes. It presents with fever, chills, and other systemic symptoms, but it does not typically cause breathlessness or encephalitis.

 

Option D. Ebola virus: Although Ebola can be associated with bats, it primarily causes hemorrhagic fever and is less associated with respiratory symptoms or encephalitis compared to Nipah virus. Also, Ebola is more commonly linked with direct human-to-human transmission or through contact with infected animals' bodily fluids.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Nipah virus should be considered when a patient, especially in South Asia, presents with fever, respiratory symptoms, and encephalitis, and has a history of exposure to fruit bats

questions.text: You're a clinician in a busy urban sexual health clinic, and it's been a hectic day with multiple patients presenting with sexually transmitted infections (STIs). The STI treatment kits are color-coded for efficient management, but the new nurse seems a bit overwhelmed with the options. You decide to guide her. Based on the clinical presentation, which color-coded STI kit would you suggest for the following symptoms? [INICET MAY 2021]
questions.solution:
Ans. (b) A-4, B-1, C-3, D-2

 

A. Lower abdominal pain:

 

  • Correct Kit: Yellow, Kit 6, which includes Cefixime, Metronidazole, and Doxycycline, specifically designed to manage symptoms like lower abdominal pain, which can be associated with pelvic inflammatory disease or other related conditions.

 

B. Urethral discharge:

 

  • Correct Kit: Grey, Kit 1, which contains Azithromycin and Cefixime. This kit is ideal for treating symptoms like urethral discharge, which can indicate infections such as gonorrhea or chlamydia.

 

C. Non-herpetic genital ulcer:

 

  • Correct Kit: White, Kit 3, equipped with Azithromycin and Penicillin, suitable for treating non-herpetic genital ulcers, often caused by syphilis or chancroid.

 

D. Vaginal discharge:

 

  • Correct Kit: Green, Kit 2, which contains Secnidazole and Fluconazole, tailored for treating vaginal discharge that could be due to bacterial vaginosis or yeast infections.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The National Aids Control Organization (NACO has provided color-coded kits for the syndromic management of sexually transmitted diseases:

questions.text: Mucormycosis can be caused by following except? (FMGE JANUARY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Broad spectrum antibiotics

 

Mucormycosis is an opportunistic fungal infection. This invades very rapidly to the surrounding tissue and even into orbit and then cranium, black eschars are formed.

 

It can be life-threatening if not attended immediately with surgical debridement, FESS and anti-fungal (Amphotericin-B) medication.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Neutropenia: This condition involves a lowered count of neutrophils, a type of white blood cell that helps prevent and fight infections, making the body more vulnerable to fungal infections.

 

Option B. Uncontrolled Diabetes: High blood sugar levels can impair neutrophil function, making diabetics particularly susceptible to fungal infections like mucormycosis.

 

Option C. Prolonged or High-Dose Corticosteroid Therapy: Steroids suppress the immune system and reduce the body's ability to fight off fungal infections.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Risk factors for mucormycosis are:

 

  • Uncontrolled diabetes
  • Prolonged or high-dose corticosteroid therapy
  • Post - organ transplantation
  • Neutropenia
  • Intravenous drug use
  • Prolonged hospitalization
  • Immunodeficiency

questions.text: Which of the following conditions would have the highest levels of ACTH and cortisol? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Cushing’s disease

 

Among the given conditions, the levels of ACTH and cortisol will be highest in Cushing's disease.

 

Cushing disease occurs when a pituitary adenoma, a noncancerous (benign) tumor on the pea-size pituitary gland, secretes too much adrenocorticotropic hormone (ACTH).

 

Normally, ACTH levels are higher in the early morning but not as high as in Cushing's disease.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Early morning: Incorrect because, although cortisol levels are typically highest in the early morning, they do not reach the levels observed in pathological conditions like Cushing's disease. This diurnal variation is normal, with peak levels upon waking and declining throughout the day.

 

Option B. Normal individuals with dexamethasone administration: Incorrect because dexamethasone is a synthetic steroid that acts similarly to cortisol. In normal individuals, administration of dexamethasone typically suppresses ACTH and cortisol production through negative feedback mechanisms.

 

Option C. Addison's disease: Incorrect because Addison's disease is characterized by adrenal insufficiency, where the adrenal glands produce insufficient cortisol and often underproduce aldosterone. While ACTH levels might be elevated due to lack of feedback inhibition, cortisol levels are low, not high.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Cushing's disease specifically leads to elevated levels of both ACTH and cortisol due to an ACTH-secreting pituitary adenoma, distinguishing it from other conditions listed that involve different regulatory mechanisms of these hormones.

questions.text: A 5-year-old girl was washing her doll with shampoo containing rotenone. Her mother noticed her in an unconscious state. Which is inhibited by the above chemical? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) NADH dehydrogenase

 

Rotenone is a potent inhibitor of Complex I in the electron transport chain, which is also known as NADH dehydrogenase or NADH oxidoreductase. Complex I is responsible for transferring electrons from NADH to coenzyme Q (ubiquinone), a crucial step in cellular respiration and ATP production. By inhibiting Complex, I, rotenone disrupts the electron transport chain, leading to a significant reduction in ATP synthesis. This inhibition can result in decreased cellular energy and potential cellular damage, which explains the unconscious state observed in the child.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Succinate dehydrogenase: This enzyme is part of Complex II in the electron transport chain, which is not affected by rotenone. Complex II facilitates the transfer of electrons from succinate to coenzyme Q, bypassing Complex I, which is why rotenone does not inhibit this step.

 

Option C. Cytochrome C: Cytochrome C is a small heme protein that plays a role in electron transfer between Complex III and Complex IV of the electron transport chain. Rotenone does not affect Cytochrome C, as it acts upstream at Complex I.

 

Option D. Cytochrome oxidase: Also known as Complex IV, this enzyme is responsible for transferring electrons from Cytochrome C to oxygen, the final electron acceptor. Inhibitors of Complex IV include cyanide and carbon monoxide, not rotenone.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Rotenone specifically inhibits Complex I also known as NADH CoQ oxidoreductase (NADH dehydrogenase) in the electron transport chain, blocking electron flow and ATP production.

questions.text: What is the likely diagnosis for a 34-year-old experiencing headaches, palpitations, and episodic hypertension?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Pheochromocytoma

 

The triad of headaches, palpitations, and episodic hypertension is indicative of pheochromocytoma. This condition is caused by the release of catecholamines, such as norepinephrine, from a tumor typically originating in the adrenal gland. The excessive release of these hormones can lead to headaches, palpitations, and episodes of high blood pressure.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Adrenal adenoma: While adrenal adenomas are tumors of the adrenal gland, they do not secrete catecholamines.

 

Option C. Migraine: Migraine does not explain the palpitations and episodic hypertension.

 

Option D. Temporal arteritis: Temporal arteritis, an inflammatory condition involving the blood vessels, can present with headache but not the other symptoms.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The classic triad of headaches, palpitations, and episodic hypertension is strongly suggestive of pheochromocytoma, a condition characterized by the excessive release of catecholamines (e.g., norepinephrine) from a tumor, typically originating in the adrenal gland.

questions.text: A 4-year-old child with weight for height less than minus 1 SD & height for age is minus 2 SD. What is the best possible assessment?  (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Chronic malnutrition

 

Chronic malnutrition, also known as stunting, is indicated by a height for age that is significantly below the normal. According to World Health Organization (WHO) standards, a height for age that is less than minus 2 standard deviations (SD) from the median of the reference population is indicative of stunting. In this question, the child has a height for age of minus 2 SD, which points to chronic malnutrition.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Acute malnutrition: This is typically indicated by a significant weight loss over a short period, reflected in weight for height measurements. A weight for height less than minus 3 SD from the median would indicate severe acute malnutrition, but in this case, the weight for height is less than minus 1 SD, which is not sufficient to diagnose acute malnutrition.

 

Option C. Acute on chronic malnutrition: This would be indicated if the child had signs of both chronic malnutrition (height for age less than minus 2 SD) and significant recent weight loss. However, the weight for height is only less than minus 1 SD, not indicative of acute malnutrition.

 

Option D. None of the above: This is incorrect as chronic malnutrition is clearly indicated by the height for age of minus 2 SD.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Chronic malnutrition is diagnosed when a child's height for age is less than minus 2 standard deviations from the median of the reference population, indicating stunting.

choices.text: MgSO4 causes uterine relaxation, but is dose dependent
MgSO4 is continued upto 24 hours after delivery or last attack of seizure
It has inhibitory effect on cerebral cortex thereby preventing seizures and lowering the BP
In renal failure, MgSO4 loading dose can be given, but maintenance dose should be adjusted based on renal function

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding MgSO4 is false? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) It has inhibitory effect on cerebral cortex thereby preventing seizures and lowering the BP

 

The statement that MgSO4 has an inhibitory effect on the cerebral cortex thereby preventing seizures and lowering the BP is false. MgSO4 is indeed effective in preventing seizures, particularly in the context of eclampsia, due to its action on the cerebral cortex. However, it does not lower blood pressure. Instead, its primary role is as an anticonvulsant and a tocolytic (uterine relaxant), not as an antihypertensive agent. MgSO4’s role in managing hypertension is minimal, and it is not used specifically for blood pressure control.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. MgSO4 causes uterine relaxation, but is dose dependent: This statement is true. MgSO4 is used as a tocolytic to relax the uterus in a dose-dependent manner. It helps in managing preterm labor by relaxing uterine contractions.

 

Option B. MgSO4 is continued up to 24 hours after delivery or the last attack of seizure: This statement is true. Magnesium sulfate is continued for 24 hours after delivery or the last seizure to prevent recurrence of seizures and to provide adequate time for stabilization.

 

Option D. In renal failure, MgSO4 loading dose can be given, but the maintenance dose should be adjusted based on renal function: This statement is true. In patients with renal failure, the loading dose of MgSO4 can be given, but the maintenance dose should be carefully adjusted due to impaired excretion of magnesium, which could lead to toxicity.

 

Educational Objective:

 

MgSO4 is used for preventing seizures in eclampsia and causes uterine relaxation but does not lower blood pressure.

 

Ref: Page no 1867, Williams Obstetrics 26th edition

questions.text: The following are the phases of:(FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Demographic process

 

Explanation:

 

Demography is the scientific study of human populations, and demographic processes are the key factors that influence population dynamics. The five main demographic processes mentioned in the image are:

 

  1. Fertility: Related to childbirth and reproduction
  2. Mortality: Related to deaths and life expectancy
  3. Marriage: Formation and dissolution of marital unions
  4. Migration: Physical or geographical movement of people from one place to another
  5. Social mobility: Movement of individuals across social classes or socio-economic status

 

These processes collectively determine the size, structure, and distribution of populations over time.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Demographic dividend: This refers to the economic growth potential resulting from a population's changing age structure, typically when the working-age population is larger than the non-working-age population. It is not directly related to the five processes listed.

 

Option C. Demographic cycle: Also known as the demographic transition model, this describes the stages a population goes through as it transitions from high birth and death rates to low birth and death rates. While related to demographic processes, the stages of the demographic cycle are not the same as the processes listed.

 

Option D. Human Development Index (HDI): This is a composite statistic developed by the United Nations to measure and rank countries' levels of social and economic development. It takes into account life expectancy, education, and per capita income. HDI is not directly related to the five demographic processes mentioned.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Fertility, mortality, marriage, migration, and social mobility are the five main demographic processes that influence population dynamics and are studied in the field of demography.

questions.text: A 32-year-old married woman who came for the evaluation of infertility was found to have a septum in her uterine cavity. What would be the appropriate management of this case? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Hysteroscopy and septoplasty

 

Explanation:

 

 Hysteroscopy and septoplasty:

 

  • Uterine septum is a Mullerian anomaly where the uterine cavity is completely or partially separated by a septum. This can lead to infertility, recurrent abortions, preterm labor, fetal growth restriction, malpresentations, and retained placenta.
  • The diagnosis of a uterine septum can be confirmed through hysterosalpingography (HSG), 3D ultrasound, MRI, or hysteroscopy. Hysteroscopy is the gold standard for both diagnosis and treatment.
  • Hysteroscopic resection (septoplasty) is the appropriate management as it involves minimally invasive surgery to remove the septum, which improves reproductive outcomes.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Hysterectomy: Hysterectomy, the removal of the uterus, is not an appropriate management for a uterine septum in a woman desiring fertility. This would completely eliminate her ability to conceive and carry a pregnancy.

 

Option B. Laparoscopy and metroplasty: While laparoscopy can be used to visualize the external uterine anatomy, metroplasty (surgical correction of the uterus) is better performed via hysteroscopy for a uterine septum. Laparoscopy is more invasive and not the first-line approach for this condition.

 

Option D. Laparotomy and metroplasty: Laparotomy is an open surgical procedure that involves a larger incision in the abdomen. This approach is unnecessarily invasive for the correction of a uterine septum, which can be effectively managed with a less invasive hysteroscopic approach.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The appropriate management of a uterine septum, especially in a woman seeking fertility, is hysteroscopic resection (septoplasty), which involves minimally invasive surgery to remove the septum and improve reproductive outcomes.

 

Ref: Page no 47, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Gynecology 6th edition

choices.text: A - Glucose, B - PAH, C - Bicarbonate and D - Inulin
A - Glucose, B - Bicarbonate, C - Inulin and D - PAH
A - PAH, B - Inulin, C - Glucose and D - Bicarbonate
A - Inulin, B - Glucose, C - Bicarbonate and D – PAH

questions.text: Identify the correctly matched pair of substances with their renal clearance from the graph given below? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. A - Glucose, B - Bicarbonate, C - Inulin and D – PAH

 

The correctly matched pair of substances and their renal clearance is option B.

 

 

The concentration of the substance changes as it passes through the tubules. Removing the substance from the filtrate is k/a tubular reabsorption and adding more of the substance to the filtrate is k/a tubular secretion.

 

Amount of the substance finally excreted = Amount Filtered + Secreted - Reabsorbed

 

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Understanding the renal handling of different substances such as PAH, inulin, bicarbonate, and glucose is crucial for assessing kidney function and diagnosing various renal disorders. Each substance's behavior in the nephron informs clinicians about different aspects of renal physiology, such as filtration rate and tubular function.

questions.text: Which of the following drug used in ADHD is a Selective Norepinephrine Reuptake Inhibitor? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Reboxetine

  

Reboxetine is a selective norepinephrine reuptake inhibitor (NRI) primarily used as an antidepressant. It selectively inhibits the reuptake of norepinephrine, enhancing its concentration in the synaptic cleft, which is beneficial in treating ADHD symptoms. Although it is not commonly used as a first-line treatment for ADHD, it can be prescribed off-label in certain cases due to its mechanism of action targeting norepinephrine, which plays a significant role in attention and impulse control.

 

Note – Atomoxetine is a selective norepinephrine reuptake inhibitor (SNRI), used in treating ADHD, but not mentioned in option.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Modafinil: Modafinil is a stimulant that promotes wakefulness and is used primarily for conditions like narcolepsy and sleep disorders. It is not a selective norepinephrine reuptake inhibitor and works mainly by influencing dopamine pathways, making it unsuitable as an answer.

 

Option C. Methylphenidate: Methylphenidate is a central nervous system stimulant commonly used to treat ADHD, but it works primarily by inhibiting the reuptake of dopamine and norepinephrine rather than selectively targeting norepinephrine alone.

 

Option D. Guanfacine: Guanfacine is an alpha-2 adrenergic agonist used in the treatment of ADHD. It does not inhibit norepinephrine reuptake but instead works by stimulating alpha-2 receptors, which reduces sympathetic nerve impulses, leading to a calming effect.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Reboxetine is a selective norepinephrine reuptake inhibitor (NRI) that can be used off-label for ADHD, distinct from other ADHD medications that target both norepinephrine and dopamine or act on other neurotransmitter systems.

choices.text: Due to opening of Na+ and closure of fast K+ channels
Due to slow but prolonged opening of Ca2+ channels
Due to closure of Na+ and opening of slow K+ channel

questions.text: Identify the true statement regarding the point marked on the myocardial action potential curve?(NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Due to slow but prolonged opening of Ca2+ channels

 

Explanation:

 

Marked point on the myocardial action potential curve represents the plateau phase, which is due to the slower and prolonged opening of calcium channels.

 

Two types of voltage-gated Ca2+ channels (T- and L-types) are present in myocardial cells. The opening of the slower L-type Ca2+ channels are mostly responsible for changes in the action potential. The action potential curve of cardiac muscles consists of 5 phases, as shown.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A: Incorrect because it mentions both the opening of sodium channels and the closure of fast potassium channels, which is characteristic of Phase 0, not the plateau phase.

 

Option C: Incorrect as it attributes the phase to the closure of sodium channels and the opening of slow potassium channels, which more accurately describes the repolarization phase (Phase 3) of the myocardial action potential.

 

Option D: Incorrect because the Na+/K+ ATPase pump, which helps maintain the resting membrane potential, is not the primary driver of the changes observed in the plateau phase.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text:
All of the following statements about proto-oncogenes are true except? (AIIMS MAY 2021)

 

  1. BRCA1 is an oncogene.
  2. HER2neu is amplified only in a fraction of breast cancer.
  3. EGFR (+) is seen in non-small cell lung cancer.
  4. N-MYC is a tumor suppressor gene.
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 1, 4

 

Statement 1: BRCA1 is an oncogene.


This is false. BRCA1 is not an oncogene; it is a tumor suppressor gene. Mutations in BRCA1 are associated with an increased risk of breast and ovarian cancers, but its normal function is to help repair DNA damage, thereby preventing cancer formation.

 

Statement 4: N-MYC is a tumor suppressor gene.


This is false. N-MYC is not a tumor suppressor gene; it is a proto-oncogene. N-MYC is involved in the regulation of cell growth and division. Amplification of the N-MYC gene is commonly seen in neuroblastoma and small-cell carcinoma of the lung.

 

Other Options:

 

Statement 2: HER2neu is amplified only in a fraction of breast cancer.


This is true. HER2 (also known as ERBB2) is a proto-oncogene that is amplified in approximately 15-20% of breast cancers. This amplification leads to overexpression of the HER2 protein, which promotes cell proliferation and survival.

 

Statement 3: EGFR (+) is seen in non-small cell lung cancer.


This is true. EGFR (Epidermal Growth Factor Receptor) is often overexpressed or mutated in non-small cell lung cancer (NSCLC), leading to uncontrolled cell growth.

 

Educational Objective:

 

BRCA1 is a tumor suppressor gene (involved in DNA repair) and N-MYC is a proto-oncogene (associated with development of neuroblastoma).

 

 

Ref: Robbins pathologic basis of disease 8th edition 521-528
